conclusion: The problem involves finding the minimal angular velocity necessary for a dipole to reverse its orientation in a magnetic field.
The dipole consists of two small balls with charges +q and -q connected by a rigid massless rod of length d.
The dipole is parallel to the XY-plane and placed in a uniform magnetic field perpendicular to this plane.
Initially, the dipole is aligned with the X-axis and has an initial angular velocity in the XY-plane.
The center of mass of the dipole is at the origin with an initial velocity parallel to the XY-plane, given as zero.
The dipole experiences a torque due to the magnetic field, given by the cross product of the magnetic moment and the magnetic field.
The magnetic moment of the dipole is calculated as q times the vector d.
The magnitude of the magnetic moment is qd.
The torque is calculated as mu B sin theta, where theta is the angle between the magnetic moment and the magnetic field.
Initially, theta is 90 degrees, so sin theta equals 1.
The torque causes angular acceleration, which is related to the moment of inertia of the dipole.
The moment of inertia of the dipole about its center of mass is calculated as 1/2 md^2.
The angular acceleration is calculated as 2qB/md.
To reverse its orientation, the dipole must rotate by 180 degrees, which is pi radians.
The initial kinetic energy due to rotation is calculated as 1/4 md^2 omega_0^2.
The work done by the torque to rotate the dipole by pi radians is calculated as 2qdB.
For the dipole to reverse its orientation, the initial kinetic energy must be at least equal to the work done by the torque.
The minimal angular velocity omega_min necessary for the dipole to reverse its orientation is calculated as sqrt(8qB/md^2).
